text:
I've made these brownies twice and the 2nd time was the charm. The amount of sugar in this is incredible ... the first batch made following the recipe "as is" created too-sweet brownies we couldn't finish. The 2nd time, however, I cut the sugar in half, added walnuts and butterscotch chips to the chocolate chips and kept everything else the same. They were fantastic! This recipe is a great base and I love that it's flexible enough to allow for less sugar and still be superb.

text:
This is what a brownie should be!  I whisked the flour, which meant I used far less than if I hadn't (measured after whisking).  I also used 1/2c yogurt with 1/2c butter.  Also used 1/3 vanilla sugar (sugar with vanilla beans stuck in a jar for about a month), along with white and brown sugar.  Not cakey at all, very moist, dense, rich brownie: perfect for brownie sundae!  Thanks Brooke.

text:
Omg thank you for a fabulous, great, awesome recipe! These came out fudgy, chewy, crispy on the edges, and the perfect height. I followed directions exactly, except adding an extra 1/2 cup of chocolate chips. My 9x13 is glass, so I have to figure out the timing better, they were a bit overcooked on edges, undercooked in middle at 35 minutes. I turned down 20 degrees at that time after finding out that glass dishes should cook at a lower temp and I cooked prb about an add'l 10 minutes. But these will be a definite keeper! Thank you so much!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I originally rated this lower, years ago.  I was searching for a brownie recipe to be topped by homemade salted caramel, and came across another recipe on another site that was the same as this.  I had made this multiple times, and it constantly turned dry.  This time, I was determined--considering it had high reviews--to make this right. I mean, 2k+ people can't love dry dense brownies, right?  
 
This time, they turned out freakin' spectacular.  I did NOT use my KitchenAid (*sigh*), instead opting for a wooden spoon so I couldn't overmix.  I also took these out of the oven right. at. 35. minutes. They continued to cook in the pan and came out wonderfully with the caramel. They were thick (1"-1.5") and fudge-like.  This time, I did it right, and man, were they awesome :)

text:
baked this recipe today - the brownies are really good and rich.  I am currently eating them hot out of the pan.  I think they are good hot - hopefully they are the same once they are cool.  I did have to bake them a lot longer than the suggested 35 minutes.  I bake a lot and dont ever have this issue - so I'm not sure why, I just hope they dont dry out as they cool.  Either way - not the recipe's fault if they do. Only change I made was using dark chocolate chips.  UPDATE: Okay, I'm pregnant so give me some slack, but these were so good I ate the whole pan by myself with the exception of three pieces that I barely shared.  I like fudgy, chewy brownies - most of the pan was like this - but the edges were crusty like a lot of people want.  Perfect brownies either way.

text:
These brownies tasted very good and the instructions were so easy that it only took me a few minutes to mix up the ingredients. However, once they were baked and cooled when I tried to get them out of the pan they just kind of crumbled apart. Instead of being able to eat these with our hands we had to get out the plates and forks because they were falling apart. Not sure what went wrong, but they still tasted good. I will probably try making them again, but if it's still really crumbly then I will look for a different recipe. The taste IS phenomenal though! Thanks for the recipe.

text:
These are awesome. My only changes were using Milk Chocolate chips (WIHOH), using a glass 8x11 pyrex (Increased cooking time 10 minutes) and not melting the butter first. I dumped the butter, vanilla, sugar an eggs in to my kitchen-aid with the paddle attachment and creamed till smooth. Than I added sifted ingredients and chips. The batter was THICK but just press into the prepared pan best you can. They are for those who like them rich and sweet but if you don't, try them with a scoop of vanilla ice cream to cut the sweet! =D

text:
So I've tried this several times and ways (using only 2 C sugar and the 1/2 brown/white sugar) and they are PERFECT (indeed the best!) if you follow the recipe with one exception;  35 min is too long in my oven. They are done in a large double batch pan in 30mins and a smaller 9x13 in 28mins.  When I tried altering the sugar they were drier and cakeier than I like them.  If you don't like things super sweet (as I don't) a better modification would be to use less chocolate chips-- and to make sure you use the semi-sweet and NOT milk chocolate chips in the first place.

None
country:
None
text:
My husband is always craving brownies, but he doens't like "cake like" brownies.  I like making things from scratch, not from a box.  So I tried these.  They are good.  Extremely rich though.  Maybe that's a good thing because I cannot eat these all day even if I wanted too.  I made small changes- I used half brown sugar and half white sugar- but I still used a total of 3 cups- they are very sweet.  I wonder how 2 cups would taste?  I used milk chocolate chips vs semi-sweet because I don't buy semi-sweet.  Another thought- if you are adding nuts, I suggest decreasing the amount of salt you add to the mix.  I tasted the batter after adding the salt- yummy.  Then tasted it again after adding the nuts-salty!  I know the recipe doesn't call for nuts, but what are brownies without walnuts!

text:
These are THE BEST brownies I've ever had. My family loves chocolate and sweets. Usually our go-to brownie recipe is 1 box of chocolate cake mix, 1 small box of chocolate pudding and a bag of chocolate chips, which are really moist and chocolatey. We though those were the best ever and declared we never would make any other brownie. Well last night we wanted some and didn't have the stuff for those and I found this recipe, so we decided to try it. These are SO much better! Really easy, and solo delicious. They wre moist, chocolatey, dense, fudgy, just perfect! My whole family said they could eat the whole pan! And I agree!! Like other reviews mentioned, I used 1 1/2 c. Sugar and the other half brown sugar. I made no other alterations. Perfect just the way they are! Right out of the oven, they are gooey and yummy, and I think they're even better the next day warmed up in the microwave a little. Now, I am serious when I say I WILL NEVER MAKE ANOTHER BROWNIE!

Yummmmmmmm! So, easy to mix in one bowl.  I used coconut oil instead of butter (making the brownies dairy free).  Coconut oil is such a healthy alternative for butter and they turned out even better than when I have used butter! I, too, used less sugar. I liked this recipe so much, and it was so easy, that I removed all of my brownie recipes from my recipe box and this is now my "go to" brownie.

text:
Despite the rave reviews, this recipe does not quite work. There is too much butter and sugar in there, which gives the brownies a caramel like shell and a mushy inside. Even after 40 minutes in the oven, they were still not quite done and we ended up eating them slightly undercooked. 

I cut the sugar by 1/2 cup, but I should have cut it by a whole cup. They were disgustingly sweet! I shudder to think what the taste and texture would have been like with three whole cups of sugar.

I'll revert to my old favourite, the 'Deep Dish Brownies' from this site, which are amazing by the way.

text:
These brownies are beautiful! Chewy and oh so chocolatey.  I don't know why people thought they were not thick enough...with 4 eggs, if beaten properly and long enough the volume of the mixture doubles and continues to rise when baked.  They were a good 2" thick.  I made 2 minimal changes, and that was to use 2 1/4 cups of sugar instead of 3 - 1/2 white 1/2 brown.  This is because I just don't like brownies too sweet.  the other change was I used a chopped up bar of Trade Joes dark chocolate instead of the chips because that's all I had at home.  A fabulous recipe - Thanks for sharing it.  it will definitely become the brownie recipe we use in this house!!

text:
It's way too sweet for my taste. I even decreased the sugar to 2 3/4 cup. It hurt my teeth biting it. I had already suspected it, therefore I didn't put the full amount of sugar. Probably 2 to 2 1/2 cup of sugar would be enough. I noticed the recipe doesn't call for baking soda either. However, I followed the recipe exactly, except the amount of sugar. I don't want to rate a recipe based on changing things here and there, that's not fair. My husband, on the other hand, loved it. He said it was really good, and not too sweet at all. So if you love everything extremely sweet, this recipe is for you. If not, I recommend you try Best Brownies recipe. So far, that's the perfect one for me.

text:
These were just okay.  The brownies were so overpowered by the sweetness of them, that I actually felt they lost some of the true chocolate brownie flavor to them.  I did not add chocolate chips into them, but I could only imagine how rich and sweet they would be if I did so considering how sugary they already were.  They do have a very fudgy consistency to them, which I like over cakey brownies, but that's about all they had going for them.  Other than not adding the chocolate chips, the only thing I changed was substituting 1/2 c. of apple sauce for 1/2 of the butter.  Everything turned out the way it was supposed to, I just didn't care for them.  Will definitely find a new recipe next time.

text:
This were great! The only change I made was to use 1.5 cups white sugar and 1.5 cups brown. And I mixed it all by hand. I had to bake it for about 37 mins for the middle to get done and by then the edges were a little overdone and hard, but besides that, the rest of the pan was simply fantastic --rich, chewy, fudgy, decadent -everything a great brownie should be! Thanks for sharing the recipe, will definitely be making it again and again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
FINALLY! The chewy, fudgey, chocolatey brownie that I have been searching for.  I halved the recipe.  Baked it in a 11 X 7 mini cake pan.  Did substitute light brown sugar for 1/3 of the sugar that was called for, used white sugar for the rest.  Used white patent flour (was all out of all-purpose). Made 12 good sized brownies about 3/4 of an inch thick that are the perfect consistency (not cakey and not too dense).  Stirred all ingredients by hand. Super simple to do and easy clean up. My fiance said that they may be the best brownies he's ever had (and he never was a huge brownie fan although I love him in spite of that).

text:
Very good, but very rich.  These were my first attempt at brownies from scratch and they couldn't be easier and tasted better than boxed.  These would be great with other kinds of chips (peanut butter, caramel.....).  One nice thing about this recipe is the unsweetened cocoa makes for not very good tasting batter which is good for people like me who eat more of the batter than they put in the pan.  You won't eat the batter but you'll love the brownie.

Excellent Brownies! Chewy and chocolate-y. I overcooked them slightly because my toothpick didn't come out clean even at 45 mins. I ran out of butter last time and substituted the rest with yogurt (had vanilla yogurt on hand) and used half whole wheat flour and they tasted great.  Going to make them for a school bake sale now, exactly as the recipe calls, I'm confident they will turn out super! Thanks Brooke!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Making this recipe was beautifully simple. As always I melted the butter over the stove, half with direct heat, then take it off and let the rest melt from the residual heat. The batter came together without a flaw, and for once I followed it to a T.  I had to cut this recipe in half since there's no way I could give away 24 servings. So I tried baking a half-recipe in an 8*8 pan, and that leaves the question of how long I should bake them for. Since my oven runs hot I tried 25 min and it was still hot. After 32 they seemed to pass the toothpick test, but when I cut into some of them the test had lied. So I put them in for 36 and they were much crunchier than I liked, but delicious nevertheless.   Next time: If you insist on cutting the recipe in half then put them in the oven for 34 minutes exactly, then let them sit for 5 minutes. Then cut.  So wonderful.

I think these brownies were amazing, even though they were a bit hard the next day. It may be because I have a major sweet tooth, but I didn't think they were too sweet, and enjoyed the cocoa flavor. 10 stars!! These are WONDERFUL! The recipe is perfect the way it's written I'm sure. The only change I HAD to make was that I ran out of white sugar at 1.8 cups, so I had to use brown sugar for the remainer to make 3c total. And my name is Brooke so I just had to make them for that reason too. lol  OH, I also made 12 mini bite size brownies with my Wilton mini muffin pan and the remainder was in an 8x11 so they'd be a little thicker then-Great size and bite size is always fun. text:
The way to bake brownies and not get the crispy hard edges and undercooked middle is the cook them at a lower temperature for a longer time. I did mine at 325* for 50 minutes and the texture was good. As for the flavour, these were only ok for us. The recipe has WAAAY too much sugar in it! The flavour was more fudge than it was chocolate ~ and I even added 2 squares of melted unsweetened chocolate to try to fix that. 1 star for the recipe as written, 3 with my added chocolate. I might try again reducing sugar to only 2 cups. Update: my brownies got hard the next day too. It is due to the amount of sugar in the recipe. Not good.

text:
OMG!! These are AWESOME!! I ended up baking them for around 45 minutes..but remember they have chocolate chips in them, when you check to see if they are done (you might get a chocolate chip, and think they aren't done yet) ..Also, be sure to use your mixer when adding the eggs....these don't have baking powder in them, and you need to beat a little air in the eggs..that's what gets them thick, and chewy, then stir in the flour mixture....SO GOOD!! Twice as thick as box mix brownies, and chewy! YUMM!!!

userID:
4738098
Display Name:
Jae C.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

6
favoritesCount:
119

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used a 9x13 pan and baked for the recommended 35 minutes. Checked it with a toothpick and it came out a little wet. (Remember this recipe does have chocolate chips so you may end up stabbing through a melted chip.) I took it out and let it cool for 10 minutes.  Then cut them into pieces. It was still warm. The edges were done and crunchy; the centers were ooey and gooey. Be cautious when removing from pan after baking; they are soft and crumble.   The next morning, the brownies were firm but centers will still chewy. Cut your portions and use a spatula to avoid it from crumbling. Brownies are just as good the day after as they are warm from oven.

country:
None
text:
Fantastic! Honestly by far the best brownies I've ever made. I've made these three times now. Once with white sugar (my boyfriends favourite, tasted just like a perfectly chewy traditional brownie), once with brown sugar (my favourite, had a hint of caramel flavour), and once replacing the eggs with milk and oil (BAD idea! Never again...it turned into chocolately soup...but that's what I get for trying to make brownies without eggs). Just so you know, when made with just brown sugar, these brownies are really difficult to cut and make look nice. If you're making them and want a nice presentation, I would suggest sticking to just white sugar as the recipe calls for. The only modifications I made were to add more chocolate chips. I used one bag milk chocolate and one bag white chocolate chips each time I made them. Next time, I'm going to try to making them Rocky Road style and add peanuts and marshmallows on top.

text:
I made this recipe at least three times before I decided to write a review. This recipe was so delicious but I had my own modifications, I originally halfed the recipe: I mixed 1/4 cup butter and olive oil to ensure moisture. 1 1/2 cups of organic cane sugar 1 tablespoon pure vanilla extract (not good with imitation) 2 cage free veggie fed eggs 3/4 cup whole wheat flour 1/2 cup hersheys cocoa powder 1/2 tsp celtic sea salt 1/2 cup natural chocolate chips  This recipe was so delicious my sister and I loved it and she rarely likes to try new recipes that I make! Next time Im gonna try adding white chocolate chunks!

text:
I was hungry for brownies, but it's just my husband and I and a full batch would have been too much for us, so I halved this recipe and made it in a 9x9" pan.  It halved very nicely and the result is a pretty thick, rich brownie.  I melted the chocolate chips with the butter, since I don't like hard little bits of anything (nuts or chocolate) in my soft, chewy brownie.  I also used 1/2c brown sugar and 3/4c white sugar.  They just came out of the oven about half an hour ago, and are still quite warm and good, but I'm betting the flavor will be even better once they cool and the flavors have time to meld a bit.

Too much sugar! Ok, I made my 1st batch based on the reviews of 1/2 and 1/2 white mixed with brown sugar.  Out of curiosity, I made a 2nd batch the next day (being that the 1st ones where gone) but this time I went exactly by the instructions of 3 cups of white sugar...oh goodness, it was like i made a sugar bar.  I had to trash them because the sugar was overwhelmingly too much!  This is a great recipe, but follow the advice of everyone else and use less white sugar, (also it would't hurt to use a little more flour (2 cups instead of 1 1/2))  Otherwise, these are some great brownies. Good Luck!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are the ultimate brownie for someone wanting that perfect chewy, fudgy, dense brownie. I followed the recipe exactly except that I left out the chocolate chips since I am not a fan of morsels in my brownies. I made two batches. I cooked the first according to the recipe and they turned out great, except that I agree if you leave the brownies out uncovered overnight the edges will harden a bit. I think this is common sense though... Just cover them, or reheat and they are just as delicious as fresh out of the oven. I cooked the second batch a little less time than the first and in my opinion they turned out even better. If you take them out right before the middle is done, then once they cool they are absolutely fabulous! This is the best recipe I have found. It is very sweet though, so if you're looking for a light and caky brownie, this recipe is not for you.

I chose to keep the amount of sugar (against my better judgement) based on other reviews, but would reduce it if I made these again.  The only thing keeping me from doing this is the fact that the day after they were absolutely nothing like the yummy brownies I took from the oven the night before.  They hardened very quickly, and seeing as we don't eat a whole tray/pan in one sitting....kind of a big deal.

Display Name:
Abby Cornine

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3552205.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took CookinginFL's advice and whisked the dry ingredients together and it worked beautifully. The first time I made these, I followed the recipe exactly and the turned out perfectly fudgey and delicious. The second time I made them, I experimented a bit.....I was trying to make the brownies a bit more healthy since I could not control myself around the first batch. So I replaced 1/2 of the butter with lowfat organic yogurt, and reduced the sugar to 2 cups. I also used a 6 ounce bar of baker's semisweet chocolate finely chopped instead of the chips. I honestly cannot tell that these brownies are lower in fat than my first batch. In fact, I think they are even better! Just be sure to only bake these....no matter how you make them....for 30 minutes. Then stick them in the fridge for 30 minutes before cutting them. This ensures the fudgiest texture! A++!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
You must try these brownies. I rarely make a recipe more than once in a short period of time and I've made these twice in the past week, they're so good. And here are a couple of changes I made to make them healthier: I substituted 1/2 c of Fat Free Greek Yogurt (Vanilla flavored) for 1/2 c of butter. I added the yogurt after I mixed the remaining 1/2 c of butter with the sugars and the vanilla to get the right texture first. I used 1.5 cups of white sugar and 1 c of brown sugar (so 1/2 c less than the recipe calls for) And beyond that - I followed the recipe and made sure to not over bake. THEY ARE VERY GOOD - and I'm a homemade-brownie critic. These will be chocolatey and fudgey and with the adjustments, healthier indulgences that don't taste like reduced fat! Enjoy!

text:
These are the BEST!! radawesome and super delicious, delectable, scrumptious brownies = BROOKE'S BEST BOMBSHELL BROWNIES I did use half brown and half white suger.  I also beat the sugar, butter, vanilla extract, and eggs for 10 minutes in my stand mixer to create the crunchy top on the brownies.  After I mixed in all the dry ingredients + chopped dark chocolate, I popped them into a 9x13 glass baking dish.  I was so lazy that I didn't grease it, but anyways.. after 35 minutes, they came out of the oven.  They are fudgy and oh so chocolatey.  At first, I thought 3 cups of sugar was a lot, but after I tried one, it tasted just spectacular.  My cousins and I devoured them with vanilla ice cream on top and homeade caramel sauce.  :P Just the night before, we had blondies, vanilla ice cream, and a maple-butter sauce with walnuts!  LOL I will always use Brooke's Best Bombshell Brownies nowadays (goodbye to the Best Brownies recipe on this site hahahaha).  Thanks Brooke, you are the greatest!!!

WOW WOW WOW!  These are THE BEST brownies I've ever made!  And oh so easy to make!  I had to bake approx 60 minutes until the toothpick came out *semi* clear.  These brownies have a gooie center, and crispie shell.  And if you're like me and think the sides are the BEST part, well, this brownie is PERFECT for YOU!  They are great for topping with ice cream!  These would also be great with peanut butter chips instead of the semisweet chocolate chips.  Thanks, Brooke!  I'm keeping this recipe!  :-)

Amazing brownies! I have used brownie mixes for years because I'd never found a recipe that was better than a good mix. After making these today I'll never use a mix again. Followed the recipe except for using reviewers suggestion to mix sugars half white and half brown. Also, when baking wedding cakes I always use Dutch processed cocoa. It's darker and the chocolate cake comes out with a bit more bittersweet flavor. It worked wonderfully in the brownies. Just awesome brownies, can't wait to make them again!

text:
i was afraid to make these at first because i had a dinner party to bake for and it seemed like a bad time to try a new recipe. but after all the stellar reviews, i caved. boy, am i glad i did! these were intensely good! i made a few small changes. i added a bit less than a tbsp. of instant coffee, used milk chocolate chips to offset the dark chocolatey flavor, subtracted a 1/4 a cup of sugar from the 3 that were called for, and used a half cup of light brown sugar in place of some of the white sugar. they came out flawless. these perfect, fudgey squares restored my faith in the homemade brownie.

text:
These brownies "seduced" me!  The BEST brownie I have ever had.  Perfect brownie texture, not dry at all and just gooey enough.  Packs an awesome chocolate punch (I used dutch processed cocoa)!  After reading other reviews I subbed 1 c of brown sugar (with 1 1/2 c white sugar) and I added 1 t baking powder and 1/2 t baking soda to the flour mixture. These come together fairly fast and easy.  I will NEVER make a box mix again!

For my boyfriend's birthday, I wanted to make him a double layer round cake made w brownie batter.  This recipe was PERFECT!  Instead of a heavy frosting I used chocolate coolwhip between the two layers and on the outside. text:
I've made two double batches of these brownies.  The first was awesome!  The next week I made them again, and the first pan (which cooked about 37 min. and I forgot to cool on the rack) was perfect.  The second pan (which cooked for 35 min. and did cool on a rack) was not nearly done enough.  I brought them to work before I cut them, and was embarrassed when they were raw in the middle.  Those extra few minutes of baking make all the difference!

The author is right, these are definitely an ultra intense treat!  But I would say that's an understatement!  These are so over the top intense and rich that they can really only be eaten in VERY small amounts (I'm a chocoholic, and I love dark chocolate, sweets, etc. and I could only handle about a 2-tbsp serving size!).  This was, amazingly enough, wayyyyyyyy too rich for me.  And it wasn't very brownie-ish in texture - almost like not very dense fudge?  I hate to say it, but as far as comfort food, and satisfying chocolate cravings, this was too much.

text:
Amazing brownies.  This recipe is a keeper if you like an intense soft fudge like brownie.  I think you need all 3 cups of sugar otherwise you are going to loose some of that rich chocolate taste and it could end up a little bitter with all the cocoa added.  If you like a sweeter brownie, add the milk chocolate chips instead.  Goes down amazing with vanilla ice cream.  I served these brownies to my husband and 4 kids while still warm from the oven and litterally half of the 9x13 pan was gone.  This recipe is a keeper. Note:  If you are a dieter, trying to watch what you eat ... these brownies will blow the diet!

text:
I was hoping for THE perfect brownie. I like really chewy brownies and I think I baked these too long (even though I followed the directions for the 'toothpick test'), although the sides did soften overnight and they were better the next day. It was almost there, although, I can't say I've baked a LOT of brownies in the past. These were a 8 or 9 out of 10 for me; a touch too sweet. I think these were the right thickness for the pan (about an inch, finished). So, these were a touch too dry for me. I got a request for nuts next time- this recipe is definitely for the purist.

Thanks Brooke!

text:
I've tried making brownies from scratch before, and they always fall short, but these were darn good on my first try.  I followed this recipe as written, with two simple changes, as suggested by other reviewers: I cut the sugar to 2 cups (half white and half brown), and I used milk chocolate chips.  I had only baked them for 25-30 minutes when they tested done, and next time I plan to underbake them even more-- I like a moister, gooey brownie.  Overall, a GREAT recipe.

text:
These were good brownies. However, like some of the other posters, they did take a ridiculously long time to cook- well over an hour. They were still soupy at the 40 minute mark when we were getting ready to take them out of the oven!  They were really tasty while piping hot- but as they cooled they did get hard and crispy. Probably because they had to bake so long. Next time I might try cutting this recipe in half and bake it in a smaller pan, and see if it cooks up better.

text:
I tried these tonight for Superbowl Sunday. My daughter didn't want me to make brownies from scratch, since most recipes in the past have turned out a little dry, or too "cake"-like. These were absolutely PERFECT! They were perfect for a 9 x 13 cake pan, and were not too flat like some are baked in that size pan. I did use the Nestle swirled morsels instead of the plain semi-sweet chips, since that is what my family usually requests when available, but the texture was perfect and the taste would be wonderful either way, I would imagine. They were chewy, even the sides! This is a keeper, for sure! Thanks Brooke - this will be my permanent, and ONLY brownie recipe!

I was a little skeptical because several reviewers called these brownies "fudge-like" and I'm not a fan of fudge, but I figured 500 positive reviews had to mean something so I tried them anyway. These brownies were GREAT! I followed other reviewers' advice and subbed one of 3 c sugar for brown, but other than that followed the recipe exactly. The chocolate chips are what really makes this so amazing. Definitely worth taking the time to sift the flour and cocoa powder so you don't get clumps. I will never buy boxed brownies again!!

text:
These were so delicious and perfectly fudgy.  The only thing I changed was the sugar.  I used 1 1/2 c. brown sugar and about 1/2 c. white sugar.  Then I used the mini semisweet chips and just eyeballed the amount.  I always set my timer for less, so I set it for 30 min and just added 4 min until I got the consistency I wanted.  They are divine.  I tried another recipe on the site with high ratings, but this one definitely is my favorite.

text:
I followed the suggestion of others about the half/half white/brown sugar, I also used semi-sweet chocolate squares (melted) instead of chocolate chips.  Lastly, we only had spread butter, so I used butter flavored crisco.  

All that said, these are quite yummy.  They have that fudgy quality that makes a brownie a brownie.  And they demanded that I go to the fridge and pour myself a glass of milk before I could even finish them.  That's what makes them so good in my opinion.  

Thanks for the recipe- my sister's already asked me to make them again.

Display Name:
psipsina01

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These really are incredible. Dense and chewy, with a bit of crunch. As per suggestions from other users I reduced sugar to 2 1/2 cups (1 1/4 white, 1 1/4 brown). At 2 1/2 cups our sweet teeth  were plenty satisfied. Other than that I did everything as per Brooke's original. Although the directions didn't say one way or the other, I mixed all of this by hand to ensure the dense and chewy consitency was not compromised. I find today's mega-watt hand mixers can reek havoc on baked goods like cookies and brownies (you end up with  drier, more cakey outcomes). I baked them for 37 minutes and even though the toothpick did not come out clean I didn't want to risk over baking so I pulled them out and let them cool in the pan. They were perfect, two minutes any more would have been too much. For what it's worth I live at sea level and cook in a gas oven. Thanks Brooke, this will be the brownie recipe used in my home.

Holy mother of brownies. From-scratch are usually dry, cakey, and inferior to my standby box: Betty Crocker Hershey's Triple Chocolate. Brooke has figured it out, though! Dense, rich, and fudgy, with a perfect crust on top and on the corners. These are almost better when cool or the next day, which goes contrary to all of my baking maxims! Try these and you may never buy a box again.

Fantastic!  I usually stick to the box mix brownies because they are the most moist and the chewiest...but these were perfect!  I use dark swiss chocolate broken into pieces instead of chocolate chips, and the darkest coaco I can find.  I am using an oven in europe...and have to leave them in a bit longer. userID:
1690069
Display Name:
J. Vincent
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:

14

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First of all, these brownies are good.  But they're not great.  I've been on a quest to find the best brownie recipe, hoping to match the brownies made by my friend's mom from my childhood.  The brownies she made were in a whole different class, and only once did I taste a homemade brownie that had a similar taste.  I did half brown sugar and left out about a tablespoon of white sugar.  I also chopped up semisweet chocolate instead of using chips.  These bombshell brownies make good, fudgy brownies, but they're a bit cocoa-y, and you have to make SURE you add the extra chocolate bits (they really make them better, even though I wasn't wanting to put them in) and UNDERCOOK the brownies!!!  If you cook them for the recommended time, you'll get cakey brownies, so keep your eye on them.  The time to take them out of the oven is RIGHT before you start to smell them, so it's tricky.
  I've tentatively decided that cocoa is what makes these and brownies not as good as they can be, not the best flavor, so I'm searching for a recipe that uses melted chocolate, or maybe I'll try dutch cocoa.  I'm going to try the Barefoot Contessa one next.

So, in conclusion, use half brown sugar, leave out just a bit of white sugar, undercook them as much as possible, put in the semisweet chocolate.  Then they are good brownies, but again, not the best.

text:
These are seriously the best.  I prefer thick, fudge-like brownies as opposed to soft, cake-like ones, and these are definitely the former rather than the latter.  The butter came together easy and was a snap to put together.  To make it even easier I microwaved the butter as previous reviewers suggested.  The recipe calls for a large bowl and, trust me, you need A LARGE BOWL.  This makes tons of batter.  Very chocolatey and the chocolate chips are a great addition.  I had no problem with the brownies turning "grainy" after a couple days; mine are *still* tasty, but now that they're a few days old they taste better when warmed up with a little bit of ice cream.  Mmm!  I'll never use another brownie mix after finding this recipe!

text:
Finally, a brownie recipe that I absolutely love.  I have tried & tried to find the perfect recipe and this is it!!  I followed an earlier review the first time I made them and added 1/2 tsp baking soda because I like the top to be a little crispy and they turned out not so good -- puffed up on the sides and flat in the middle; although the flavor was great.  I made them again following the recipe exactly and they were brownie perfection!  The only tip I have for those who don't like the chocolate chips in the recipe is to chop them up or use finely chopped chocolate instead.  I don't like to bite into bits of chocolate in my brownies either, so I used the chopped chocolate and it was perfect -- no chocolate chunks and really chocolatey.  Thanks so much for sharing this recipe!! :0)

text:
Everyone loved these, these brownies are delicious! Very dense, moist, and extremely chewy even several days after baking. I added somewhere around 3/4 cups of walnuts by special request and they were a bit hit! I used a baking dish slightly smaller than 9x13 so with the remaining bater I added one shot of espresso and baked it in 2 oven-safe teacups which was a delightful presentation of a rounded puffed mocha brownie. The regular bar brownies were delicious but I really liked the addition of espresso in the teacup ones I made, so next time I make these I will add some espresso and leave out the nuts. I also used high quality dark semisweet chocolate baking bars and chopped it roughly which gave an amazing fudgey aspect to the brownies. So delicious!  I will make this recipe again but play around with the recipe a little to make it perfect for me.

I'm from the Netherlands and i always bake my brownies using a mix. I get these mixes (famous brands) in America or Canada. But now i've run out of mixes and i had to look for a recipe. I found this one and WOOOW!! I'm never using a mix again. These brownies are soo good. I also used 1,5 cup brown sugar and 1,5 cup white sugar. The only ingredient i can't get here is vanilla extract but lucky enough i stacked up a lot of bottles!! These brownies are so fudgy and sweet and rich. I already called my mum to tell her she doesn't need the mix anymore and send her this recipe. this is the best!

If I could give this recipe more than 5 stars, I would. I think I just died and went to heaven. These brownies taste like those that you'd get at the most amazing restaurants! Otherwise made it just as written.  Be very careful not to overbake these, or they will lose their yummy fudginess!

text:
These were good, but not fantastic. I did follow suggestion and use half brown and half white sugar. They were very sweet, I think next time I will cut the sugar down to 2.5c. Also, the vanilla flavor was a little strong for my liking, maybe 1/2 tbsp would work better. I made two batches and added about 1c chopped walnuts to one of the batches. I preferred those to the plain ones. Not a bad recipe, I will continue tweaking it to my liking.

text:
I love these brownies, they are awesome just the way they are! But to add just a little more decadence, I pulled them out of the oven about five minitues early and added about 1/2 bag of mini marshmallows and then finished baking. After baking, I topped the melted marshmallows with chocolate frosting: 1-2/3c powdered sugar, 1/2c butter, 1/3c cocoa powder, 1/3c canned evaporated milk. Sinful!

text:
This is a pretty good recipe. I made it exactly as directed, with the three full cups of white sugar, no brown sugar. They are fudgy; I didn't think they were eggy, and I felt they tasted best the day they were made. I liked the richness of the chocolate--lots of cocoa powder, and I used bittersweet chocolate chips because I am a true dark chocolate fan. I do think maybe 3 cups of sugar is a bit too much; I think that the next time I make them I will try decreasing the sugar and maybe try it with the brown sugar variation. Also, next time I will probably add some espresso powder to deepen the chocolate flavor. this is an easy recipe and a pretty good one, but my favorite brownie recipe uses melted chocolate; this is slightly faster and less expensive to make though.

These were definitely better the next day. When I tried them warm, all I could taste was egg. Probably just me, since nobody else would admit to tasting it. ;) The next day though, they were great. Easy recipe to follow, and just as good as a mix, IMO.  I can't imagine how anyone is getting 'cake' from this mix - these are the complete opposite of cakey!  This time, I didn't have any chocolate chips, so I added half a bag of Heath bits.  This is a great recipe that far surpasses boxed mixes.

text:
My 10-year-old made these by herself and theyre the best brownies Ive ever eaten in my life. Perfectly fudgy with the thin layer of crustiness on top. When she got them out after 35 minutes she was going to check them with a toothpick. I told her no because it would have batter on it no matter what. If I hadnt been in there, she probably  would have tested and put them back in the oven.  I could tell they were done. They are remarkable. For people commenting about the sugar... they're a treat, and an excellent one at that. They dont taste like straight sugar. They actually have  a wonderful richness to them that I couldnt believe came from just cocoa powder. We will never use another brownie recipe. Thanks, Brooke!

The texture of these brownies is amazing. However, I couldn't bear how rich they were. Neither could the rest of my family. Too sweet, and too dark for our taste. I had even cut back the sugar by 1/3 of a cup. But it was still over the top for us and  my kids didn't even finish them. I would like to try them again by using half the sugar and less cocoa and see if we can find our sweet spot, because I can imagine they'd be perfect if just a little less rich.

Display Name:
Michelle

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5821539.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this in a 13  9 in pan. I made everything according to recipe, except: I added 1/4 tsp baking soda for the crackly top, 1/4 tsp garam masala, and some pecans. I forgot to fold in the chocolate chips and pecans, so halfway through the brownies, i put a layer of pecans, and put 1/2 the chocolate chips on top of them (so they wouldn't sink to the bottom). Mixed the last half with the remaining batter and smoothed on top of the pecans/chocolate chips. I sprinkled a tiny bit of chili powder on them at the end to give more of a warming effect. Brownies were thick, and as gooey as skillet brownies, and the top was super crackly and crispy (baking soda). This recipe makes a ton of brownies, but it is worth it. Boyfriend doesn't want to share them with his coworkers. 
You won't regret making these!

text:
Made as directed to the T with a 13x9 at 350 for 30 minutes and these are exactly as described in the recipe description! Chewy edges, fudgey underbaked-like centers...which is just how I like my brownies. If this is your type of brownie then this is a great recipe for those who purposely underbake other brownie recipes (except this one holds its shape...even in the center pieces). Admittantly the chocolate flavor may be just a LITTLE too rich for me personally, but I think this can easily be fixed with subbing the chocolate chips for chopped nuts. For those who messed with the sugar measurements or complained about the sweetness of these....its a brownie for darn sake!! Its supposed to be overly sweet and not very good for you....sheesh some people...if you wanted a "skinny" brownie why dont you add the word HEALTHY in front of brownie recipe in your search bar, instead of underating a perfectly good recipe because it wasn't exactly want you wanted. READ THE RECIPE DESCRIPTIONS BEFORE MAKING....good lord.

Great recipe, highly customizable. This is a really good recipe, the brownies are rich and fudgy.  I put most of the chocolate chips on top and added chopped walnuts. After everything came out of the oven and comes for a few minutes I drizzled caramel sauce over the top to make turtle brownies.  The only things different that I would do were changes I made to the recipe. I would use caramel candies and add them at the end of cooking time and I didn't wait long enough for them to cool before trying to cut them.

text:
Tastes awesome! For the powdered cacao, I took whole, organic cacao beans --hulled them and powdered them. I used 2 cups of date sugar (contains several minerals) & 1 cup of organic cane sugar.  Added 1 cup of chopped walnuts, floured the chips so they would not drop to bottom.  Baked at 325 degrees for 25 min. due to having  a convection oven.  Waited 45 min. before cutting into them.  Wonderful!!  They taste best the next day, after being in the refrigerator overnight.

Sherree Durham Totten

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6427636.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was surprised by how thick the batter was and thought Id added too much flour or cocao powder, but they turned out great.  I live at a semi-high altitude (Denver), did not modify the recipe, and baked in a 9x13 glass pan.  The brownies ended up being a little over 1 thick.  I baked for 30 minutes and they seemed a little raw inside so I added 5 more minutes.  After they had cooled, I realized I shouldnt have given them the extra 5 minutes as the edges are crumbly vs chewy.  The middle is chewy, bordering on dry.  3 out of 4 of us loved these brownies, so Ill try again to perfect it.

text:
These brownies are fantastic!! They do not have any baking soda or powder in them, so make sure to beat the eggs into the butter/sugar mixture to until light in color/ribbon stage and then gently fold in the flour/cocoa (Mary Berry style). Made them in a 9x13 and they are perfect height an oh so fudgy!! Great find on this Blizzardy day in MN!!

userID:
24911746
Display Name:
JEANNE WALLINGFORD
isPro:
False

0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6239669.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this exactly as written without the chocolate chips because I wanted to taste the brownies themselves. These are very good brownies. For those who are worried about the amount of sugar, I just want to point out that any recipe calling for unsweetened cocoa will likely have a good amount of sugar to offset the bitterness of the cocoa. I did not find these brownies to be overly sweet and perhaps that's because I omitted the chocolate chips. One thing I always do when using cocoa is to "bloom" the cocoa by heating it. For this recipe I added the cocoa to the butter since I needed to melt the butter anyway, I left it on low heat, stirring constantly for 2 or 3 minutes after all the butter was melted. Then I took it off the heat, poured it into a bowl and let it cool while I measured my remaining ingredients. I only made a half batch since it's just myself and hubby, baked it at 330 degrees in a glass 8x8 dish for 27 minutes and they turned out perfect. Great texture, flavor and thickness. The only alteration I might try next time is to add a little espresso which elevates the chocolate flavor to a whole new level. Overall, this is a great recipe that does not need to be altered.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I live at a high altitude and wasn't sure if I should adjust the recipe but ultimately followed directions. I used Hershey's Special Dark cocoa powder (it's what I had on hand) but I wish I had used a regular cocoa powder. Dark cocoa powder made these slightly more bitter than I would have liked but that is my fault, not the recipe's. They are moist, dense, and using butter (not margarine) produces a flakey top. If you're planning to frost these, I'd use margarine (produces a smoother surface) so the frosting is easier to spread. Delicious.

Display Name:
Noah George

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6195284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First i tried the most popular cake brownie recipe here and realized i like chewy brownies better. I made these with the listed amounts of cocoa and sugar, but added in 3/4 cup walnuts. I waited an hour for these to cool and tried one. It was absolutely horrible. it tasted way too rich and bitter. I was pissed that i wasted my ingredients on this. I could only stomach a bite and that was it. gross. So then I went to bed.  The next afternoon, I was getting ready to throw out the ziplock full of these things but decided to take another bite. I was thinking perhaps if I reduced the cocoa it would be better. But when I tried them again, they were absolutely perfect. perfect chew, sweetness, and chocolate.  So what I learned is that this is the best recipe out there, but it needs 24 hours to rest so all the cocoa can be fully absorbed and you will be rewarded.  After the wait, these are fantastic. Next time i'll use butterscotch chips to try something different.  I hope these keep in the freezer.

text:
Ohhhhhh my goodness - SO delicious!! I cut the recipe in half and used an 8x8 pan. Also added 1/4tsp baking soda per other reviewer's suggestions. The only issue is that it kind of collapsed in the middle, leaving a huge crack down the center of the whole batch. Maybe if I made the whole  9x13 pan of them they wouldn't have done that. Whatever though, they tasted amazing!! (I'm one of those people who love cold desserts/chocolate, so I can't wait to try them tomorrow after they've sat in the fridge all night!) *UPDATE*. Yep. Even better the next day. Cold or zapped in the microwave for around 30secs. These are incredible.

text:
These are very good, just insanely rich.  Only change I made was white chocolate chips (because that was what I had on hand).  There may have also been a small issue with the thickness of the brownies in the pan, since the edge seems a bit overdone compared to the middle, but that would just be experimenting with a different pan.  I'd make them again, but maybe find a way to dial down the richness, though my wife had no complaints.

My daughter made these for me for my birthday! They were everything I wanted them to be. It was the right balance of cakey vs fudgey. I was in chocolate heaven! The sweetness was on point and then the bonus of the chocolate chips. She used dark chocolate chips. My daughter added walnuts to  the recipe because hey, brownies need walnuts! I enjoyed my brownies with a scoop of ice-cream and a drizzle of chocolate fudge on top while still warm. It tasted like a restaurant dessert!  Even my husband, who doesn't care for brownies, loved them! It really was a very happy birthday for me!

I just wanted a smaller treat and not have a whole batch of these things around, so I made a 1/4 recipe. I put in 1/4 tsp of baking soda but other than that, I followed the recipe... except I forgot to put the chocolate chips in! Over all, it was really good, even though I forgot the chocolate chips. I made 6 cupcake sized portions but I should have made 7 because they spilled over. Since I was using a convection oven, I reduced the temp to 325F and baked them for 25 minutes, which was perfect. I didn't find them too sweet and I don't typically like sweet treats.

Display Name:
SThornton

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these as directed using extra-large eggs (I think large is the industry standard for recipes). The texture is the best I've come across (and I'm on a quest to find the perfect brownie recipe). The inside stays together and is super moist and fudgy, and the outside is crisp--maybe a bit *too* crisp. The outside is where I particularly noticed the absence of oil. It is borderline tough. I used Ghirardelli chocolate throughout, but will go back to Pernigotti unsweetened cocoa powder; nothing equals it, IMO (Williams-Sonoma, Whole Foods, etc.) Finally,  I also thought they were a touch too sweet (and I have a sweet tooth). Next time I'm going to cut back sugar 1/4 cup and maybe add a touch of espresso powder. For now, this is my new go-to recipe. Thanks, Brooke!

Display Name:
Karla Hisatomi

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4117867.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used organic raw cane sugar instead of white sugar and lessened the amout of sugar by about half a cup, which was still very sweet. The sugar has its own taste but my boyfriend and I love it. I used milk chocolate chips and lightly tossed them in flour before adding them to the batter so they wouldn't fall to the bottom and it worked! I halved the amount of butter and substituted in plain yogurt, lowered the amount of salt to around 3/4 of a tsp and used himalayan pink salt because it was the only salt I had, and added a 1/2 tsp of baking soda to create a crispy top which worked wonders. When I cut into the brownie, the knife crackled the top easily and then dove like butter into the fudgy inside! I also used gluten free flour because it was the only flour I had, and if you like the consistency of it it's wonderful and gives it little bits of chewy(?) goodness, maybe like a moist cornmeal? My boyfriend went nuts for this brownie and overall I will make it again, maybe healthier next time haha!
Review:
Rating:
4

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been trying various online & cookbook brownie recipes for the last few years trying to find one we really liked.  This has ended my search.  

I had some mint/chocolate chips to use up and wanted a good brownie recipe to put them it - these were the best brownies I've ever had.I read the reviews, an made a few changes - I decreased the sugar from 3 cups to 2.5 - used half brown sugar/half white. I used dark cocoa because that's what I had.  Also added 1/4 tsp of coffee extract to enhance the chocolate.  Baked at suggested temp in convection oven for 15 minutes less than suggested, then topped with 1.5 cups of Andes mint/chocolate chips and let melt.  When cooled, cut & ate we ate every single one.  I will be making these brownies way, way too often in the future.

I made a recipe of these topped with Blonde Brownie I, doubled.  I made the Blonde dough first and put it in the fridge while I made the brownie batter, then dropped the cookie dough in blobs over the brownies, topped with bittersweet chocolate chips (the extra dark kind). text:
I decided at the last minute to make these for a super bowl party and I loved that it required so few ingredients, all of which I had on hand.  

HOWEVER...

I also had way too many s'more ingredients in the house, so I crushed together 6 graham crackers, a couple cups of mini marshmallows and broke apart a couple Hershey bars and sprinkled that on the top after the brownies had already baked about 20 minutes.  I then continued baking them the remainder of time needed.

OH....MY.....GOODNESS!!!  They were absolutely decadent!!!  

Fabulous!  Definitely doing this one again.

text:
These were SOOO good! I made half the recipe, just to try it out, see if my family liked it. I wish I doubled the recipe, they were gone in a day! I have tried several other recipes, they have all ended up tasting like squares of cake. Definitely not this one, it was dense and rich.  Better than the box, I definitely will make these again, maybe it will become my go-to recipe. Though I did make some minor changes. I used a half cup of brown sugar and a cup of white. For a full recipe that would be a  cup of brown sugar and 2 cups of white sugar. I also doubled thew amount of vanilla. That is just my preference, I am a vanilla addict. Thanks!!!! :)

city:

None
country:
None
text:
These were wonderful!  They are like a brownie fudge hybrid.  The rich, soft texture is divine.  I made mine into turtle brownies by topping them with 1C of semi sweet chocolate morsels and 3/4 C of chopped pecans prior to baking.  I then drizzled my warm pan of brownies with a Carmel sauce I made using 1C of Carmel Bites and 2T of milk prepared in the microwave at 1 minute on high, stirring, then 10 second intervals until the Carmel was nice and creamy.  These turned out so amazing that Im making more to take to my folks and my Sister as a just because I love you surprise.

text:
I made these brownies, but had to make a few adjustments to the recipe.  First of all, I cut out a half cup of the sugar just because we dont like to consume so much sugar.  Then, I only had three eggs , and didnt want to buy more since we will be leaving for out winter home shortly.  Because of that, I also cut the flour by half a cup.  Surprisingly, these brownies turned out great.  They are dense, very chocolatey  and not too sweet.

text:
Like a fellow reviewer I am only giving 1 star so that bakers know that for this recipe the toothpick test will not work. This is because of the morsels. They will always leave the toothpick covered in chocolate no matter how long you cook. Instead move the pan back and fourth and watch the waves of the brownie firm up to a solid state and you will know its done. Great recipe otherwise!

text:
I am so happy I found this recipe. They are very rich and delicious. I decided to just use a cup of brown sugar and a cup of reg sugar instead of 3 full cups of sugar. I under baked just a tad (some people complained about the brownies drying out) and they were outstanding. I tossed the chocolate chips in flour so they wouldn't sink, and used mini semi-sweet chips. This will be my new brownie recipe!

Best brownies in the world!! I was on a quest to find the most delicious, fudgy, and decadent brownies, and these sure hit the mark! I halved the recipe and baked the brownies in an 8x8 pan for 25 minutes. They were perfect to get out of the pan and very easy to cut. text:
I will so make this recipe again and again.  In fact, this is my new go-to brownie.  The amazing thing about this recipe is that it makes a crunchy cookie-type layer across the top and the center is fudge-y, without being dough-y.  Some described it as between cake-like and fudge-like, which is what won me in the first place.  The only thing i changed about this recipe is that i omitted the chocolate chips and replaced with one and a half cups black walnuts.  Oh, they are divine!  I will never make another brownie: this one is it!

text:
These are hands-down the best brownies I've ever tasted. They are ridiculously-chocolatey-rich, thick, and chewy with that delectable, necessary shell of crisp on top that names your heart go pitter-patter when you bite into a brownie.. I followed another reviewer's advice to add 1/2 tsp of baking soda to encourage the shell, and I think it definitely made the difference. Be aware that this is basically a double-batch, hence the large quantities of ingredients.

OMG There is a terrible thing going on with these brownies. They are the most addictive things I've ever eaten. I start and cannot stop, especially when I throw them in the microwave for 30 seconds, drop a scoop (or two or three) of blue bell vanilla ice cream and drizzle it with Ghirardelli chocolate syrup. By far, the best brownies EVER! 
I did make a few adjustments to the recipe. I used 1/2 c. Hersheys Special Dark cocoa powder and a 1/2 c. Hersheys unsweetened cocoa powder. I also doubled the chocolate chips. We like it rich! 
Oh so good!

text:
I made the recipe as written. Today I took these brownies to a work potluck.  The positive response was overwhelming.  Everyone really enjoyed these, whether plain or ala mode ( I brought Breyer's 'homemade' vanilla ice cream to go with).  I think these are really rich and fudgy, which is how I like my brownies. I used 60% cacao chocolate chips (a shade past semi-sweet on the scale) and that adds both richness and takes the edge off the sweetness.

text:
If you like greasy foods that are extremely rich this would be a good recipe for you.  Way too much sugar and butter for my taste though.  Instead of wanting another brownie I found myself wishing I hadn't wronged myself with the first one.  Also, the toothpick test does not work well with this recipe since it is so greasy and full of chocolate.  My toothpicks were still coming out with goo after 35 minutes of baking, and the edges were all burned.  The actual flavor is not too bad if you can get past all the sugar, so it gets 2 stars for that.

text:
This recipe is great but could be a bit too sweet! I used 1 cup of brown sugar and 1 cup of white sugar instead of 3 cups of white sugar.  I added chopped almonds and chunks of unsweetened chocolate bars (from Trinidad where I'm from). The unsweetened chocolate bars added some bitterness like dark chocolate chunks. But the bitterness is just in the chunks so the rest of the brownie is sweet. For me, this add more dimension to an already great recipe!

I read a few of the reviews before I baked it and made a few adjustments.  Instead of 3 cups, I used 2 1/2 cups of white sugar.   I also reduced the salt to 1/2 tsp and added 1 cup of chopped walnuts.  If your family is as impatient as mine I would recommend you make this batch when you're home alone so it can cool sufficiently before cutting. The texture was perfect!  Very good recipe for the novice baker!

I have been baking for years , so I am not a novice.  My co-workers always ask me to bake their birthday cakes for them.  I am also asked for my recipes.    I read this Brownie recipe first then watched the video.  it  seemed simple enough so  I made this brownie recipe today.  It is  the worst recipe I have ever made !!    The Brownies came out like bricks on top and on the bottom with a mushy center.  I had to chisel them to remove them from my pan which was sufficiently greased !  By so doing I have now ruined my baking pan.   I recently made your blueberry coffee cake  which came out perfect and delicious. However this brownie recipe is very,very  disappointing.   I had to throw it out , what a waste of ingredients !

These brownies are the best homemade brownies I have made.  I did a little less than 1 1/2 c. white and a little less than 1 1/2 c. light brown sugar.  Made everything else as directed except used mini semi-sweet chips.  I baked in a 9x11" glass dish to make them thicker, and it took 50-55 min total baking time at 325 degrees.

I made this after reading all the reviews carefully and diligently. 
I've noticed so many people mentioned the level of sweetness of this recipe. I like sweet things but just occasionally. 
So, instead of using 3 cups of white sugar, I replaced it with 2 cups of brown sugar and guess what? It was still sweet to me. But it's the kinda sweet that I kinda able to stand.
Plus, I always like my brownies to be a little bit cake-y, thus using the cake method instead (beating butter with sugar etc). So the result was satisfying! Sweet still, but at least I managed to settle my craving for good ol' brownies!

text:
I followed the suggestion from previous reviewers and added in 1/2 tsp. baking soda, and then used only half of the salt- this made the top layer absolutely perfect! 

I did leave out the chocolate chips though, because I don't like anything in my brownies.

I baked this in a 10 inch cast iron skillet, and the edges and bottom turned out perfectly chewy. 

These small changes made this recipe my absolute favorite! I just deleted all of the other brownie recipes that I was planning to try, because this is the one! These turned out fudgey and chewy, and so much better than anything out of a box. My search is officially over, and I'll be making these again and again.

text:
I think this was a great base recipe. I wanted one that used cocoa powder not syrup. I did make a few changes, instead of 4 eggs, I used  2 eggs and 1/2 cup plain yogurt, used 1 cup butter and 1/2 cup coconut oil, and only 2 cups sugar, 1 cup white and 1 cup unrefined coconut palm sugar. Baked for 37 mins, but could have done 35. They came out very moist and delicious. My family loved them.

text:
For the most part, I followed CookinginFL's take on this recipe. Although, I did make my own alterations. I used salted butter and sweetened cocoa powder, I didn't add the teaspoon of salt, and I used white chocolate chips. These brownies came out just as fudge-like as anticipated, if not more so. I recommend cutting the brownies into small squares because they are so dense and rich. I was told eating half of a brownie felt like they had eaten a whole one. However, be very cautious of hard edges and a hard brownie bottom. I personally don't like crunchy edges, so I cut them off since they could not be avoided.

text:
I prefer more chewy fudge-like type brownies with crisp edges.  These did not come out that way.  I followed what others said about 1 cup white sugar & 1 cup brown sugar.  Glad I did so as it's pretty sweet & I can't imagine using 3 cups of sugar total.  Otherwise I followed the recipe and am disappointed.  This came out more cake-like.  Plus the cocoa powder taste is overwhelming.  It doesn't taste chocolately despite adding the chips.  I think I want to try a recipe where I actually melt chocolate into the batter instead.  Also, baking for the minimum 35 minutes, the toothpick came out completely clean which means it may have already been over cooked.  So I can't say I'll make this one again, but if you like more cake-like brownies, this might work for you.

text:
Amazingly yummy!  I took advice of fellow reviewers and cut white sugar to 1 1/2 c, and used a scanty 1 cup brown sugar.  Probably could have cut out a little more sugar, but they were decadent and delicious.   It is a bit tricky to know when to remove from oven.  Because of the chocolate chips, your toothpick may not come out dry, but it needs to be separating from sides nicely to ensure it will not remain too gooey to serve.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
5 stars with tiny adjustments. I used 2 1/2 c sugar ( I used 1 c. brown and 1 1/2c white sugar. Since I got rid of a half a cup sugar they needed some more wet. I added a CAP full of Kahlua (a tbsp of coffee would have been fine but my pot was empty). I used 1/4 c. special dark cocoa powder and 3/4 c. unsweetened cocoa powder. Also, the adding of each egg separately will make a thicker brownie. I only cooked mine for 32 min. They were perfect. The most delicious brownies I have ever had. I think using the full 3 c. sugar would have been way to much.

text:
These  were delicious. I put half the chocolate chips in the mix and half on top.  Next time I will put all in the mix and perhaps drizzle some melted white chocolate over the top, after they come out of the oven. Other than that the only change I made was I added 3 Tbsp. of Kahlua to the mix. This doesnt make it coffee flavored at all but just punches up the chocolate flavour. 
Oh and I greased the pan and then dusted it well with cocoa powder before hand and had no issues getting any squares out due to sunken melted chocolate chips.

text:
These turned out super yummy. They were fudgey and chewy which is what I love in a brownie. Next time I will take them out a few minutes sooner though because my oven runs a touch hot. I didn't even have them in for 30 minutes so be careful and keep an eye on them in the oven the first time you make them so you can adjust your timing to your oven. The only thing I wish was different about these brownies is that they turned out a bit thicker but they definitely would have been way too thick in a 9 x 9. Thanks for sharing your recipe! My family really enjoyed it.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was hesitant to make these after reading a few negative reviews, but I went with the majority and tried them out and I was not disappointed! The only changes I made were to use 1 cup of brown sugar and 2 cups white as a few other reviewers suggested (and because I love brown sugar), and I used half semi sweet chips and half milk chocolate chips. I also chopped the chips quite a bit before I threw them in, trying to achieve more of that melty goodness throughout, and it worked! I baked these for exactly 35 minutes, didn't check them, just pulled them out when the timer went off and they are the perfect consistency. Nice and soft, a bit chewy and not cakey at all. They are very chocolatey, but not overly sweet. My dad considers himself to be a brownie connoisseur and he said they were the best brownies he's ever had! Will absolutely make again and again!

text:
I combine this recipe with the "Best Chocolate Chip Cookie" recipe found on AllRecipes to make tasty mini muffin-sized brownie cookies (aka brookies). I'm new to baking and this combo is pretty fool proof. I fill about 1/3 of the mini muffin tin with brownie batter and then plop a ball of cookie dough (maybe the size of those small ice cream scoopers) in the center. I bake them at 350 or 375 for about 6 minutes...and then fight the urge to gobble them all up!

These brownies are delicious. When I read 3 cups, I became a bit hesitant, so I only added a smidge over 2 cups. Maybe 2 & 1/8 of regular white sugar. . Display Name:
Alana Potter

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
In my opinion, the best brownies ever are the ones you make from the Ghirardelli box mix. Unfortunately, sometimes that box mix isn't on hand when I'm craving a brownie, so I have to try to make my own. This recipe is almost as good as the Ghirardelli ones, although I think if I used a good cocoa it would be as good. 

There's a really nice crunchy layer on top. The middle of the pan is fudgy and decadent, and the outer edges are delightfully chewy. They don't need any kind of frosting or glaze or anything, although they would be wonderful with some ice cream! 

A warning: I think the issue a lot of people were having with this recipe was simply overcooking the brownies. I only cooked them for 35 minutes and they were cooked all the way through. They're supposed to be soft, and shouldn't be rock-hard or hard to cut unless baked for too long. 

I love this recipe, and will definitely use again.

text:
I wanted to try this because everyone seemed to love it or hate it. I think I made the mistake of trying to make them thicker by putting them in the next size down pan I have (not the 9x13). When I took it out after the allotted time, the center was gooey. I had to keep putting the pan back in, which make it too chewy on the outside and difficult to get a single brownie out of the pan in one piece. The batter was yummy, so I think the cooking method affected the flavor too much to rate this effectively. I might try it again exactly as the directions say, but it is not as dark chocolate-y as I was looking for, definitely more like a Hershey bar than a Ghirardelli dark chocolate or the Ghirardelli brownies.

text:
These were so good that I literally burned my tongue trying to eat them while they were cooling (although I am 8 months pregnant).  I made these for my daughters school party using a 9x13 pan and left out the chocolate chips and they were still very fudgey, chewy & dense with a strong chocolate flavor. Mine were finished in 28 minutes so keep an eye on them. Everyone loved them and you would not miss the chips. Next time I will add the chips because I will definitely be making these again & again!!  Very easy, quick dessert to pull together with in minutes.

They are still in the oven but after/during mixing they were sooo thick that it was literally like the densest dough ball I have never made. I'm kinda a new baker so I didn't realize till they went in the oven that I should have WEIGHED the flour. Even though I spooned the flour into the measuring cups I must have went way over in volume. (I did level off) I couldn't even scrape the spoon easily. I had to press it in place like a cookie or something.. Well, the alarm went off so I'm gonna go pull them. I'm impressed with how chocolatey they smelled even before baking and especially now! The whole house smells like a Toll House massacre!

DO NOT HALF SUGAR.THIS IS AN AWESOME RECIPE.  It's not too sweet.  Perfect.  Chewy edges. Thick batter and thick final baked product.  Filled my 13x9 dish. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Brilliant Recipe!
You'll know I am a very old baker when I say that for over fifty years my brownie recipe came from Mary Alden's Kids Cookbook published in the mid-fifties. That recipe also makes a fudge brownie - a " good one" according to my profane but appreciative father.  So that had been my sole recipe .... until today.  Seeing all the raves this  got and being in the mood for a change,  I made this recipe and I love it.  Chewy, fudge-like, and  moist. The only change to the ingredients was to cut back a wee bit on salt to 1/2 tsp and to add 1/2 tsp of baking powder....don't know why I did that - just felt like it. I topped the dough with a few walnut pieces and  I  lined the pan with foil which I sprayed so repacking the brownies would be easier. I am currently feasting on the edges which I cut away lest they prove too dry (they weren't) for my grandchildren and their parents who will enjoy them tomorrow as a base for really good chocolate ripple ice cream. Way to Go, Brooke!

text:
Wonderful brownie recipe! The brownies were chewy in the center and crisp on the edges. After baking and eating this version of brownies, I realized that I never had - a real brownie! Most brownies were either cake like or so hard that they could double as hockey pucks if cut correctly. 

I've heard people extol the virtues of the "chewy in the center and crisp outer edged brownie" much like Bigfoot I chalked it up  to legend. Since I have a brownie loving boyfriend I bravely followed this recipe  almost to the letter.  The only change I made was to use the Hershey milk chocolate chips instead of semi- sweet chocolate chips - I was not disappointed. 

 I made this for my boyfriend last night and he gave it the  thumbs up!  I gave him most of the tray of brownies so he could share them with his "brownie loving brothers";  yet another sign of approval.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe! They are indeed fudgy and delicious as promised. Here are the gotchyas I found:

 * The batter is a lot thicker than brownie batter sometimes is. This is fine, but just expect it. It hangs in the bowl, and you have to scrape it out.
 * Because they've got so much sugar, if you cook them too long (or too hot), they'll turn crazy hard. Better to take them out a little early than risk a sheet of rock.
 * Along the same lines, definitely take them out of the pan before they're 100% cooled. I let mine cool completely first and had to scrape them out with a knife, even though they were perfectly cooked and not hard.

Definitely worth a try!
Review:

2

text:
these brownies are SO amazingly delicious (when you alter it a little )!!!

I used half white chocolate and half dark chocolate chunks which made it sort of richer. I creamed the butter not melted it to make it lighter and more fluffy, and I used 2 and a half cups of sugar,  don't reduce the sugar too much, I know it sounds like a lot but in the mix its not too much!!!
I love these brownies, defiantly my go to recipe from now on.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
BEST BROWNIES EVER... I made exactly as the recipe except did use half brown sugar/half white sugar because that's what I had on hand. I did use mini chocolate chips and folded them in at the last second before baking so they didn't all fall to the bottom like a few raters said. They took 40 minutes, I looked for cracking on the top and no jiggle - toothpick does not work on these. They were fudgy and chewy and crunchy on the edges and chocolatey... I used a 9x12 pan.  Just the best brownies I have ever had. Next time I will try dark chocolate chips since I am a dark chocolate fan. OH! I almost forgot the cocoa powder I used was dark chocolate - that's all I keep around. Thank you, I will never make any other kind of brownie again. :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have a super sweet tooth, and yet, even reducing the sugar to 2 cups (1 1/2 white and 1/2 brown), these were sweet enough to make your teeth hurt. They were, somehow, not really fudgey nor cake-like, and, after a scant 12 hours (of proper storage) were hard as a rock. But, to be honest, my very brownie-loving family wasn't going to eat more than the first sampling, anyway-- we made them into brownie sundaes because on their own they were reasonably unpleasant. Though the batter was very well mixed, you're hit in the face with the overpowering sweetness of (again, reduced) sugar, the bitterness of (high-quality) chocolate, and vanilla-- the flavors compete, not blend. I've never had a chocolate dessert turn out this way, and certainly will not be making again.
Review:

1

text:
This recipe was very good. It was the perfect combination of fudgey but a hint of rise to it to give it less of a dense batter. It provides the perfect amount of thickness but nothing to cakey. I found this recipe very important to make in a 13x9 in pan it wont work in a smaller pan unless the recipe is cut in half. 

The amount of batter is perfect for a big family but more than I need for my small family of two. I wouldn't change a thing in this recipe it was delicious. But for me I gave it four stars because to me a brownie isn't  brownie without those hard almost burnt edges. lol

text:
Definitely the most amazing brownie recipe I've ever made! I get compliment after compliment by everyone that tries them. I've only made one small change to the recipe: I add chocolate shavings instead of chips, with a mix of milk and dark chocolate. I also sprinkle about 1/2 cup on the top for that extra bit of chocolate heaven! This recipe is extremely resilient, and allows for great experiments. I've added peanut butter, and marshmallows to change it up sometimes, and the result is always delicious!

I was bored and looking for something to bake using leftover Halloween candy. Brooke.....thank you so much for this fantastic recipe! Delicious and very fudgy...just the way my husband and I love our brownies! (We have zero tolerance for cake-like brownies). text:
Tastes great, the biggest thing is DO NOT OVERBEAT when adding the eggs; this causes the brownie to rise far too much and then collapse, resulting in overdone edges and batter spilling over the sides of the dish.  I've made the same mistake twice and only figured it out the last time; next one I'll make using a wooden spoon instead

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1346263.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these yesterday but wanted a richer chocolate flavor brownie that my chocolate holic hubby would love, and I wanted a thicker brownie that would be soft and chew.  I used 2 cups of flour, and 2 cups of dark chocolate cocoa powder along with 1.5 cups of white sugar, and 1.5 cups of brown sugar as suggested. I used five eggs, and 3 teaspoon of vanilla.  It filled my 9x13 pan nicely. The trick is don't over bake. I left them in the oven for 25 minutes.  They are the best chewy chocolatey brownies we ever had. Very rich, and I also added a cup of chopped nuts along with the one cup of semi sweet chocolate chips.  The batter is thick so I used my electric mixer. Delicious!

Display Name:
Frederick LaVan

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is, as promised, a gooey brownie recipe. I halved the ingredients listed here, added the 1/2 tsp baking soda mentioned by others to the dry ingredients, and baked the brownies in my favorite 8x8 inch oiled aluminum pan. I used 1/2 cup of mini semi-sweet chocolate chips tossed in the dry ingredients before mixing in the wet ingredients in order to keep them from sinking. I also added 1/4 cup small diced walnuts, and topped the brownie batter with a handful of scattered caramel bits before baking. The recipe, once halved, only needs to be baked for 35 mins at 350 degrees. The toothpick was not completely clean, of course, because of the chocolate chips, but it was not obviously covered in raw batter. The brownies firmed up as they cooled, and were easy to remove from the pan about 25 mins after baking. My kids are thrilled and I am thrilled because now I can make the brownies they like without a trip to the store.

text:
These were probably the best brownies I've ever had. They were fudgy and soft with a strong but not overpowering cocoa flavor. Definitely should be enjoyed with some milk.

I substituted the vanilla extract for half as much almond extract, just my personal preference though. I was also out of chocolate chips so I chopped up some Hershey's kisses and threw those in. Oh! And I think I used a square 9x9 pan rather than the 9x13.

If you're feeling experimental, throw some mini marshmallows on top after baking and put it under the broiler to brown them. Super yummy!
